At 14, Mary Fairfax (later Mary Somerville) studied algebra & mathematics, defying her father’s wishes.

Eventually, she began experimenting & writing about #science. Her interests spanned fields from astronomy to chemistry to physics. Mary published articles & books & is now celebrated as a mathematician, scientist & writer.

Along with Caroline Herschel (see earlier #HistoryRemix post), she became one of the first 2 honorary members of the Royal Astronomical Society. https://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/PT.3.3817

title: Learning to Operate in Open Worlds by Adapting Planning Models

last_post.content:
New in #AI #ML that is not #chatgpt

I am STOKED about our research on #OpenWorldLearning at #AAMAS 2023.

#OWL is a novel learning paradigm. The three waves of #AI share a common design pattern. Phase 1 - program/train the inference algorithm; Phase 2 - deploy it. If deployment finds some unhandled usecases, go back to the first phase.

#OWL breaks this cycle & builds systems that can #learn like #humans - they learn autonomously AFTER they have been deployed.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14272

But due to well-documented cognitive biases (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prospect_theory), reactions to new technology are overly sensitive to risks rather than potential gains; especially because gains are often hard to foresee.

Who would have imagined the internet, when even experts said there was a market for only five computers? Who would have imagined computational biology? 4/

And maybe we should have been afraid. Almost all modern military weapons are designed and controlled by computers. Most modern propaganda and misinformation is disseminated with the help of computers. Modern surveillance relies on computers. And computerized systems have certainly created or prolonged biases — whether economic ones or social ones such as gender bias — long before the era of modern AI (e.g. https://nissenbaum.tech.cornell.edu/papers/biasincomputers.pdf). These are important issues! 2/

title: The mechanical monster and discourses of fear and fascination in the early history of the computer - Humanities and Social Sciences Communications

last_post.content: It’s not surprising that recent developments in AI are eliciting a range of skeptical and fearful reactions. This almost always happens when technology develops. Early computers famously elicited skepticism such as “there’s a world market for maybe five computers,” but also fear (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41599-020-00650-4) — fear of their impact on society, on government, or on warfare. 1/7

Primarily intended as pre-processing/pre-viz tool for plotting/painting pieces from my C-SCAPE (https://art.thi.ng/c-scape) #CellularAutomata project, for the past few days I've been working on a new tool to do multi-pass/multi-layer vectorizations/segmentation of grayscale bitmap images and it's been coming along very nice. Parts of the project are already checked into the #ThingUmbrella repo as new example, but now it just occurred to me this all would also be a _great_ opportunity to do a little video walkthrough! The project combines quite a large number of underexposed packages & recent updates, incl. https://thi.ng/rdom for UI, https://thi.ng/atom & https://thi.ng/rstream for reactive state handling and arranging processing topologies to only execute minimum work, https://thi.ng/rstream-gestures for mouse/touch canvas viewport manipulation. Plus, of course, recent work on https://thi.ng/geom-trace-bitmap & https://thi.ng/grid-iterators, https://thi.ng/geom geometry generation and its use as single source for both drawing to canvas and SVG/hiccup export (latter also for #AxiDraw output), image processing with https://thi.ng/pixel and https://thi.ng/pixel-dither etc. Also, the entire JS bundle is currently only 31KB gzipped (all inclusive), also demonstrating one doesn't need large, bloated creative coding frameworks and instead can easily compose smaller parts to get things done... but I digress! 😇

Here're some screenshots of current version...

#TypeScript #GenerativeArt #ToolsForMaking

title: 'He Would Still Be Here': Man Dies by Suicide After Talking with AI Chatbot, Widow Says

last_post.content:
The thing to keep an eye on now is how seriously this tragic event will be taken by manufacturers, politicians, researchers and journalists and what specific actions will be taken by each.

In my post about AI responsibility in a hyped-up world I wrote this:

“And when mental illness can be intensified by a machine and lead to horrific consequences, it is easily waved away. It appears no one needs to be held responsible for the machine’s impact. Nothing needs to be regulated or recalled.

Some people matter less than others.”

The consequences can be predicted. They can be managed before tragedy strikes. The reason they are not predicted and managed is because there is no interest or understanding on the manufacturer side. So who should be allowed to be building and releasing these tools to the masses?

https://www.vice.com/en/article/pkadgm/man-dies-by-suicide-after-talking-with-ai-chatbot-widow-says

P.S. Please refer to your national health agency for information on who you can contact when you need someone to talk to for support.

#AIHype #AIEthics #DigitalEthics

title: On The Planetary Theory of Everything

last_post.content:
A new theory of everything.

Galaxy formation, dark matter, and the tension in the expansion of the universe can all be explained by the natural behaviors of an overwhelmingly large population of exoplanets.

Since planets are obviously the ubiquitous answer to every current question that can be posed by astronomers, planetary science must then be the basis for all science, and therefore that all current funding for science be reserved for (exo)planetary science.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17035

title: A Modest Proposal for the Non-existence of Exoplanets: The Expansion of Stellar Physics to Include Squars

last_post.content:
Exoplanets do not exist.

title: GitHub - bytecodealliance/jco: JavaScript tooling for working with WebAssembly Components

last_post.content:
Can’t tell you how excited I am for: https://github.com/bytecodealliance/jco

On the Rust side you can produce a WASM component using the `cargo component` commands. And on the JS side you can then just do:

```js
import myComponent from “my-component”;
```

…which with the jco command will just work! Imo that’s going to be huge for cross-language interop!

💡 NQCC — or a not-quite-C compiler — is a compiler for a subset of C that Nora Sandler worked on at RC. She also wrote a series of blog posts diving deep into various aspects of that process, which is now a book! Writing a C Compiler comes out in August and is available for preorder: https://nostarch.com/writing-c-compiler

If you can’t wait until August, you can read the series from the beginning on her blog https://norasandler.com/2017/11/29/Write-a-Compiler.html and check out the code on Github https://github.com/nlsandler/nqcc.

TIL of Schlick's bias and gain functions. The bias function is a parametric easing function that can go from sharp ease-in to linear to sharp ease-out. The gain has easing on both ends and can be likewise controlled.

Cool article: https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.09714

title: Project MUSE - Linguistics education and its application in the workplace: An analysis of interviews with linguistics graduates

last_post.content:
New article in Language from me and @AnujaCabraal

Linguistics education and its application in the workplace: An analysis of interviews with linguistics graduates

https://muse.jhu.edu/article/884307

We used the first 50 interviews from the Superlinguo Linguist Job Interviews to look at how people in a range of jobs and careers talk about their education and the skills they now use in the workplace

full list of interviews here: https://www.superlinguo.com/post/173873032222/superlinguo-linguist-job-interviews-full-list

A lot of this info and the activities are also included in the Linguistics Jobs resource set I put together with @gretchenmcc, which has been updated with information from the paper: http://bit.ly/ling-jobs

Thanks, again to everyone who participated in the Linguistics Job Interview series. And thanks to @AnujaCabraal for bringing a new perspective to the stories in those interviews.

I hope that this paper provides an overview that is worthy of all the stories people shared.

title: Brightest-ever gamma-ray burst (the “BOAT”) continues to puzzle astronomers
